item.title: 2020 年度总结 | 我们只是假装关心
item.description:
Photo by Tingey Injury Law Firm on Unsplash
 

第二篇年度总结的内容我想了很久，半个月前郑爽代孕的事件在发酵的时候，我其实写了一篇关于代孕的文章，但后来网络上舆论导向实在太难看，我就感觉可能需要进一步思考写点新东西。然而都没过几天，新的新闻爆出，大家又一窝蜂地去关注另一个大新闻，前一个新闻就只留下了一堆几周后就会过时的梗。

互联网是否有记忆这个问题，其实一点意义都没有。在互联网出来之前，人们通过电视、广播和报纸获取信息，这些媒介长期储存信息能力比互联网低多了，别说几周前了，昨天《新闻联播》的内容很多人今天就忘得差不多了。所以「互联网是否有记忆」这个表述，不过是把互联网里人的思想问题归咎为技术这一表层而已。
item.content:encoded:
Photo by Tingey Injury Law Firm on Unsplash
 

第二篇年度总结的内容我想了很久，半个月前郑爽代孕的事件在发酵的时候，我其实写了一篇关于代孕的文章，但后来网络上舆论导向实在太难看，我就感觉可能需要进一步思考写点新东西。然而都没过几天，新的新闻爆出，大家又一窝蜂地去关注另一个大新闻，前一个新闻就只留下了一堆几周后就会过时的梗。

互联网是否有记忆这个问题，其实一点意义都没有。在互联网出来之前，人们通过电视、广播和报纸获取信息，这些媒介长期储存信息能力比互联网低多了，别说几周前了，昨天《新闻联播》的内容很多人今天就忘得差不多了。所以「互联网是否有记忆」这个表述，不过是把互联网里人的思想问题归咎为技术这一表层而已。

 

诚然，热搜榜每时每刻都在变动，我们的注意力也在随着转移，但人的记忆其实很难抹除，特别是那些难以解决的我们关心的事。有什么事是难以解决但我们非常关心的呢？好像有很多，既有中美之争、疫情防控、女权这些非常宏观的问题，也有饭圈之争、「打倒」某个 KOL 这样非常具体的问题，这样的问题都能引起非常剧烈的讨论，但最后，这之中的绝大多数问题都随着新问题的到来而被遗忘。

当然，你可以用「紧急」和「重要」划分的维度来给问题的所谓重要性排个序，但这个排序显然非常具有随意性，一个与之前事件相关的新事件一出来，一些本来被划为「不紧急不重要」的事就能瞬间被推到舆论舞台中央。

所以对此我的解释很简单：我们其实一点也不关心。这不是什么技术的问题，我们可以上一秒感叹一位孩子的离世，下一秒刷到一条偶像的动态又投入到娱乐，不是因为算法，而是我们根本就不关心。时代当然有自己的问题，现代化的城市社会，确实让人都陷入一种快速变动的生活之中，但正因如此，当我们试图去就某个问题发表自己的观点，我们不关心的样子就显得尤为突出。

你可能会问：如果我们不关心，为什么还会在网上造出如此大的声浪呢？因为我们想表现出我们很关心的样子。如果你去看当下公共论理，你会发现，尽管有讲道理的人，但是这些道理不管用多么看似华丽的语词包装，归纳起来都很简单：饭圈的争斗的道理是「不能干涉其他人的正当权利」，女权的道理是「女性不应该被物化」，质疑媒体的道理是「媒体应该为人民说话」，难道这么简单的道理，争辩的对方都不懂吗？不是的，不管是说这套道理的人，还是听这套道理的人，都不是不知道这些道理大家其实都明白。为什么不去深挖一下道理，去想应该怎么解决问题呢？因为我们不关心。我们只想用发表在公共场所的言辞证明自己是一个非常正义的人，希望获得他人的肯定而已，事情根本就不重要。

如今的公共舆论场，看来看去不过是这几类言论：上面说的那种简单道理，或使用极端语词发泄情绪，以及称赞上面两类言论。前段时间代孕事件发酵的时候，我朋友圈有一位女性朋友，写了一段非常「慷慨激昂」的话（当然在我看来不过是修辞术），然后借着「你们自己也没做多好」的道德高地把评论她的男性都骂了一遍，我不知道她凭借这条朋友圈产生了什么外部性效应，不过她个人的道德表演倒是完成得相当不错，自我满足感绝对非常强。

然而这一点用都没有，没有人去思考更为具体的道理，没有人提出具体诉求去解决问题，那我们的发声还有什么用呢？在评论区 @ 这 @ 那，这就是我们口中的推进问题解决的方式？要我说，这样下去问题只可能越来越多，社交媒体最后会越来越变得像一个「充满问题」的地方，舆论本身也会愈发失去意义。

那么我们可以做什么吗？当然，和上一篇文章一样，我又得提那种「简单却不切实际」的建议了：放弃使用大道理，而是在具体问题上反思大道理。例如在女性角度看代孕，很多女性朋友都认为代孕就是对女性的物化，但是这样一概而论，当然忽视了很多细节。

譬如女性选择在 20-30 岁时冷冻卵子作为「后悔药」，这算不算掌控自己的身体？大部分女性的最佳生育期和其事业快速发展期是重叠的，有部分女性在其最佳生育年龄并没有生育愿望。但等到事业稳定下来后，可能就会有生育意愿，然而此时若错过了最佳生育年龄，卵子质量和子宫状态可能远不如之前，那么在这种情况下是否可以选择使用自己冷冻的卵子，使用他人子宫进行代孕？一位女性在其最佳生育年龄段选择追寻事业而不是回归家庭，这不也是女权主义的叙事吗？当然你也可以继续反驳这个例子，但我的目的并不在此，我只是想说当我们越来越具体地反思这些大道理时，你会发现，那些看似人人都懂的简单大道理，其实也并没有那么简单。

最后，我写这个话题的目的，也并不希望大家认为我们在过一个非常糟糕的生活，恰恰相反，我认为我们应该摆脱对于那些「唯一真理」的依赖，去想象另一种可能性，我们不必希望论辩对方按着我们的希望转换观念，我们自己转换观念，其实最终结果会好很多。

Reference

  • 在充分感到疼痛前，我不感兴趣那些宏大的道理
  • 翻电 Special 互联网道理争辩的面相学 VOL.37
  • 翻电 Special 暴力，语言的暴力，思考的暴力 VOL.40

item.title: 2020 年度总结 |“资本”竟是我们自己
item.description:
Photo by Jp Valery on Unsplash
 
 
关于年度总结
理论上来说，2020 的年度总结应该在 2021 年到来前写完。但因为经历了一些事情，整个人散漫了很长一段时间，所以拖到了现在。不过，从农历来看，现在其实还是 2020 年，所以在下个月 12 日前，我写的还是能算作 2020 年度总结的：）。

2020 年是互联网企业出事颇为频繁的一年。倒也不全是因为疫情，就我国这种互联网企业发展的架势，这一天迟早会来，疫情只是让各种尚未成熟的互联网服务及其背后的体系被提前推上舞台了中央。从 996 事件，到小黄车押金、蛋壳公寓爆雷、被困在系统里的外卖小哥、双十一快递罢工，然后到 2021 年年初的外卖小哥猝死、拼多多加班过劳死，这些事件背后的行业，是随着我国这几年互联网成长起来的，我们这代人亲眼见证了它们从无到有到繁荣兴盛的过程。

但同样是我们这代人，在面对这些互联网展现出来的问题时，却倾向于非常简单地进行归因。在上述事件的公共舆论中，「资本」和「资本家」这个词往往高频率地出现，只要大公司出了什么问题，大家就开始搬运马克思批判资本家的话语，开始谴责资本主义的邪恶。不要误会我，我并没有要否定马克思及其观点，资本主义确实是很糟糕的秩序，但是把原因归结到一两个「资本家」身上甚至是「资本」这个非实体之上，未免有些虚空打靶，而且单纯地批判也解决不了任何问题。
item.content:encoded:
Photo by Jp Valery on Unsplash
 
 
关于年度总结
理论上来说，2020 的年度总结应该在 2021 年到来前写完。但因为经历了一些事情，整个人散漫了很长一段时间，所以拖到了现在。不过，从农历来看，现在其实还是 2020 年，所以在下个月 12 日前，我写的还是能算作 2020 年度总结的：）。

2020 年是互联网企业出事颇为频繁的一年。倒也不全是因为疫情，就我国这种互联网企业发展的架势，这一天迟早会来，疫情只是让各种尚未成熟的互联网服务及其背后的体系被提前推上舞台了中央。从 996 事件，到小黄车押金、蛋壳公寓爆雷、被困在系统里的外卖小哥、双十一快递罢工，然后到 2021 年年初的外卖小哥猝死、拼多多加班过劳死，这些事件背后的行业，是随着我国这几年互联网成长起来的，我们这代人亲眼见证了它们从无到有到繁荣兴盛的过程。

但同样是我们这代人，在面对这些互联网展现出来的问题时，却倾向于非常简单地进行归因。在上述事件的公共舆论中，「资本」和「资本家」这个词往往高频率地出现，只要大公司出了什么问题，大家就开始搬运马克思批判资本家的话语，开始谴责资本主义的邪恶。不要误会我，我并没有要否定马克思及其观点，资本主义确实是很糟糕的秩序，但是把原因归结到一两个「资本家」身上甚至是「资本」这个非实体之上，未免有些虚空打靶，而且单纯地批判也解决不了任何问题。

 

法律有用吗？当然有用。不过我们也必须要明白，法律不是自动机，并不是一出问题，法律马上就能出来维持秩序，将社会调回到某种良好状态。事物的背后往往非常复杂，并不是单靠某部法律制定就能立马解决的。

回顾这些事件，我们在面对这些事件的时候，究竟忽略了什么？我们忽略了我们自己。我们这一代人太崇拜互联网了，认为互联网带来的所有便利都是理所当然的，我们之所以能享受到便捷的外卖、不断提速的快递、廉价的商品，全部都是得益于互联网。

但是互联网说到底还是用来达成目的的技术，它如何发挥作用，发挥什么样的作用，最终还是取决于背后使用这套技术的人。今天我们能享受到所谓「便利」、「实惠」的互联网产品，并不是因为互联网，而是互联网背后活生生的人。而我想说的是，正是在技术的遮蔽下，我们忽略了我们享受便利的背后究竟是什么。

互联网给我们带来了两种可能性：一是低廉的价格，便宜的「百亿补贴」商品、大额的外卖满减券、十元包月的共享单车，这些似乎都让我们用便宜很多的价格购买到商品；二是财富的增殖，主要是各种互联网金融产品，各种抓住「风口」的创业机会。

巧合的是，互联网给我们带来的这些可能性，实际上本来就是企业运营的目标。企业也像我们一样，期望着原材料的成本一降再降、期望着财报越来越好看、期望着企业管理系统运作效率越来越高，这看上去并没有什么不对的地方。企业与个人的需求在互联网上达成一致，似乎也是个不错的结果。

但是这两种可能性本身就是有矛盾的。也就是说并没有某种完美的少花钱多办事的运行模式，一旦我们想要同时达成这两项目标，总会产生其他的问题。在某些方面，可能表现为虚拟和现实的差异（譬如造假、货不对板）；在另一些方面，则是链条中的一些人会受到压榨。在当下，后者比前者其实更为常见，而互联网的存在使这种压榨更为隐形，因为你在互联网上见不到活生生的人，见不到你的几次点击会给其他人带来什么样的影响。

举个例子，我们想要在保证质量的情况下，让外卖更加便宜快捷有错吗？似乎没有。但是我们需要回过头，看看当外卖真的更加便宜快捷时究竟发生了什么。其实只需要一个简单的前提，那就是「钱不会凭空变出来」，那么在这一前提下，外卖价格下降，肯定是因为成本下降。此时，有两种方案降低成本：商家降低成本，这会导致货不对板；平台降低成本，结果是员工薪资降低或者一个人干多个人的活；配送端降低成本，结果是外卖送餐员必须一次性接多单，而这又势必会延长配送时间，而若是超过了规定的配送时间，用户会不快，平台也会克扣外卖送餐员的报酬，最后结果自不必多说，就是最近的新闻。

当然，到这里你可能会反驳说，互联网公司员工工资本来就高，也有月入过万的外卖送餐员，外卖送餐员本来素质就不高有工作就不错了云云。巧了，企业也是这么想的，所以两端都会认为，如果链条两端都能受益，那么中间层成为代价可以是理所当然的。

拼多多也是一样，我们要求商品的价格更低有错吗？似乎没有，但是「百亿补贴」的钱不是风刮来的，是投资者往这个公司投的钱。而只有拼多多的财报变得好看，股价才能上涨，才有更多投资人往里继续投钱。要想财报好看，就必须提升利润，方法同样也是降低成本或者提高价格。所以一方面，你可以看到当下的电商游戏规则愈发复杂，抢红包、挣积分、邀请人助力……越难懂、越费时间越好，反正就是要不断提高消费者的成本，变相「涨价」；另一方面，其又在自身管理上开刀，无视劳动法的加班、各种残酷的用人制度，目的也是降低人力成本。所以拼多多在其声明中说：

这不是资本的问题，这是社会的问题。

这很令人惊讶吗？要说什么东西真正令人惊讶，那就是面对一点利益而不顾任何代价，抛弃同理心的我们自己。这些公司用红包、满减这些方式问我们：你们真的可以为了这点利益什么都不管吗？很遗憾，回答是：是的，你快拿来，别磨磨唧唧的。

所以我们在说资本坏的时候，我们究竟在说什么？我们是在批判黄峥、马云这些资本家吗？我们是在谴责互联网这套「吃人」的体系吗？说到底，如果「资本」真的可以被还原为某种物质实体，那么肯定是每一个希望价格无限低、财富永续增长、永远保持高效的我们自己。

所以当我们一次次面对这样的事件时，期望系统本身做出改变，无疑是一种见效非常慢，且效果也非常差的方法。去年《外卖骑手，困在系统里》的报道出来后，我们的第一反应是呼吁两家大公司对派单系统和计算系统作出改变，把我们自己的责任撇得干干净净，甚至还去评判哪家拿出的改变方案更好（或者说，把我们的责任撇得更干净）。当然系统问题很大，到现在我也没见到饿了么「愿意等五分钟」的按钮上线，美团上的预计送达时间也没见增加，这之中确实有虚伪性。但是比起系统，从使用系统的我们开始，无疑是更有效且更直接的，我们的欲望一天不降，系统也只会变着花样对链条中间进行挤压。

到这里，解决方案非常简单，那就是我们每个人拒绝这些看似廉价便利的工具，不点外卖、不用拼多多、不参与「薅羊毛」，拒绝所有用廉价和便捷包装的糖衣炮弹。当然我知道这很难实现，我也坦率地说我很难达成，但认识到这一点，我们至少需要进行一些努力，不说彻底抛弃，至少要认识到这之中我们扮演的重要角色，至少在点外卖之前问问自己「我这外卖是非点不可吗」，在拼多多下单时思考「这个商品本身是我应该享受的吗」。

如果这都有困难，还有一个妥协较少的方案，不过听上去挺令人不快的：不因为外卖不能送到门口、餐冷了而给骑手打差评；不因为快递放在代收点而不是送到家门口而去投诉快递。不要用「我付了钱，这是我应该享受的服务」去搪塞，这跟马克思眼中资本家会说的话一模一样，因为这就是资本主义的一个陷阱——支付价格就能无限地免除责任，这当然是不行的。

当然也有很多人说，仅靠社会上一小撮人的行动也不见得能改变整体景象，个体的声量太小了。我们需要明白，社会偏好是可以被少数人塑造的，现在的黑产羊毛党，他们也是少数人，但却影响着当下电商的发展方向。

再退一步讲，做一点事，总比什么也不做更好。

Reference

  • 拼多多事件：除了抱怨 996，你真的在乎吗？
  • 美团与饿了么的方案，我们在他人困境中的角色

item.content:encoded:
Photo by Kristina V on Unsplash

 
为什么选这篇文章
我算是一个有点自由主义思想的人，2020 年算是自由主义完全溃败的一年，很多以往我所相信的东西，都在「疫情」前变得分文不值。不过仍然有人相信自由主义是有未来的，例如这篇文章，颇有种带着自由主义「突出重围」的感觉。
 
  • 中英双语
  • 中文
  • 英文

A pandemic is by necessity a time for restrictions and Big Government. But if emergency measures become the new normal, liberty dies.
大流行病必然会催生出大政府和各种管制，但如果紧急措施成为新的常态，自由必将消亡。

It’s been a terrible year for personal freedom. And I’m not just saying that because I happen to find myself in yet another lockdown.

古典自由主义的传统，是真正尊重每一个人，不分阶级、种族、性别或邮政编码，重点是：人人享有个人自由。在 2021 年，这一使命值得重申。自由就像健康一样，在它消失前，你根本不会想到它，所以我们不要等那么久。2020 非常糟糕，让我们面向更好的未来打上自由的印记。

A pandemic is by necessity a time for restrictions and Big Government. But if emergency measures become the new normal, liberty dies.

It’s been a terrible year for personal freedom. And I’m not just saying that because I happen to find myself in yet another lockdown.

Like war or other disasters, a pandemic shifts priorities. In 2020, individual liberty seemed less important and public health appeared most urgent. State paternalism suddenly looked surprisingly acceptable, or at least necessary.

But along the way, Covid-19 also became an ideal pretext for cynics and autocrats everywhere who already disdained liberty to try to bury it altogether. As 2021 dawns, is freedom in global retreat? Is “liberalism” passé?

The outlook wasn’t all that bright even at the start of 2020. In January, I penned a “liberal manifesto” because I feared that classical liberalism was going out of fashion and a new collectivism was becoming vogue. Covid-19 has accelerated that preexisting trend.

To avoid confusion, let’s be clear about the word liberal here. It has nothing to do with its American meaning of lefty, woke or big government; nor with its European caricature as “neoliberal” and market fundamentalist. We’re talking instead about a venerable philosophy that regards individual freedom as the highest value while fully recognizing the need to harmonize this principle with society as a whole.

For that reason, liberalism can occasionally live with restrictions on liberty. The harm principle, as defined in 1859 by John Stuart Mill in his treatise “On Liberty,” says that “the only purpose for which power can be rightfully exercised over any member of a civilized community, against his will, is to prevent harm to others.”

So there’s nothing inherently illiberal about, say, a lockdown to slow the spread of Covid-19. Or about a regulation that requires us to wear masks in public. Nor is it automatically illiberal for the state, in a situation of economic disruption and distress, to step in temporarily as the primary economic actor, paying firms and people until they can earn their livelihoods again.

The trouble starts when these measures are adapted, extended or abused. The world was already tilting toward authoritarianism in recent years. China didn’t need Covid-19 to oppress the Uighurs or clamp down on Hong Kong, nor did Alexander Lukashenko need it to tyrannize Belarussians. But many autocrats have seized on the coronavirus as another excuse to crack down on their critics, the free press, minority populations and others they don’t like.

Democracy and human rights have deteriorated in 80 countries this year, according to Freedom House, an American think tank. In Zimbabwe, government thugs have, in the name of policing lockdown infractions, arrested, abducted, raped or assaulted opposition leaders, activists and other dissenters. Authorities from Kazakhstan to Sri Lanka, Cambodia, Guatemala and many other places have been almost as bad.

Even where governments don’t physically tyrannize people, they increasingly censor them digitally or, under the pretext of contact tracing, build new surveillance tools. China has gone furthest, by connecting biometric, financial and other intimate information about citizens without their assent. Even democratic societies such as South Korea and Singapore increasingly have an infrastructure they could turn from transparent to Orwellian with the flick of a switch.

In mature democracies such as Germany or the U.S., checks and balances remain robust enough to prevent such dystopias for the foreseeable future. But there too the climate for democratic and civilized discourse, the precondition for any liberal society, has deteriorated.

The main culprits are conspiracy theorists, who always thrive in times of plague. They wantonly abuse the right to free speech and assembly — core principles of liberalism — to spread disinformation and lies.

Liberals will be the first to defend these people’s right to disagree with government policies or to interpret medical facts differently. But when people misuse their own liberty to impugn facts and pervert truth they are vandalizing our intellectual, psychological and cultural commons.

Another illiberal trend is economic. It also precedes Covid-19. China in particular has presented its form of state capitalism as a countermodel to the West’s open and competitive market economies. In response, Western countries have started leaning toward more state intervention.

The coronavirus has reinforced this change. Initially, the government interference was necessary. As the exogenous shock of the pandemic imposed bed rest on entire economies, only the state was left to pick up aggregate demand and prevent mass poverty.

The question for 2021 is whether Leviathan will be able, or willing, to wean economies again from the huge stimulus packages, furlough programs, bankruptcy suspensions, subsidies and other interventions. German economists, for example, warn that their country could have 800,000 “zombie companies” next year. These are firms that probably should have died and exited the market for reasons unrelated to the pandemic but were kept alive artificially by government policy.

Collectively, the world’s market economies have thus taken a big step in the general direction of central planning. As the coronavirus retreats next year, some governments will be tempted to extend this approach, also under the banner of “Green Deals” to fight climate change.

Underneath these discrete policy areas, a more general suspicion has been spreading thatmarkets, capitalism, elections, rules and entire systems are all somehow rigged. Liberalism and individualism, according to this meme, are an ideology of the elites, by the elites, for the elites — a “liberalocracy,” as the author Patrick Deneen puts it in “Why Liberalism Failed.”

This perception is at first blush understandable. Many younger adults, the so-called Millennials, having been buffeted first by the financial crash of 2008 and now by Covid-19, don’t feel they’ve had a fair shot at building their lives and are increasingly embracing “socialism.” Black people and other members of minority groups suffer daily humiliations by racist cops or other bigots. Everywhere, the poor have been hit worst by Covid-19, both medically and economically.

What has got lost in this atmosphere of crisis is that liberalism is not the source of these problems but rather the best starting point to find solutions to them. I’ve already tried to sketch two such approaches, to address climate change and inequality. Done right, a Universal Basic Income could be a reform that’s not only sensible but also liberal.

If there is a meta-crisis beyond all these problems, it may be what the historian Timothy Garton Ash calls a “disparity of esteem.” From the U.S. to Poland, societies have become polarized as people see one another less as individuals and more as representatives of rival groups and stereotypes: cosmopolitans versus bumpkins, “anywheres and somewheres,” the “woke” or the “deplorable,” those getting ahead and those falling behind. Sometimes the pain is less about feeling poor than about feeling unappreciated.

This is the psychological landscape that populists have been exploiting with so much success in recent years. But they are peddlers of resentment, the political equivalent of snake oil.

The tradition that genuinely esteems each individual irrespective of class, race, sex or zip code is classical liberalism, with its focus on personal liberty for all. It’s worth restating thismission in 2021. Freedom is like health: You don’t think about it until it’s gone. So let’s not wait that long. It’s been a bad year. Let’s make the liberal case for a better future.

  • 中英双语
  • 中文
  • 英文

Big corporations use marketing to trick us into thinking that the solution to all our problems lies in buying more of their stuff.

大公司利用各种营销手段欺骗我们，使得我们认为购买他们的商品就是解决我们所有问题的方式。

The real solution is often the exact opposite: it consists in consuming less, not more. In most cases, our problems are caused by overconsumption in the first place.

但真正解决这些问题的方式却恰恰相反：不是增加消费，而是减少消费。在大多数情况下，我们会产生问题的原因，首当其冲就是消费。

For example, if you are overweight, you will be bombarded with ads for gym subscriptions or food supplements. But the key to losing weight is eating less – not new shoes and protein powder.

譬如，如果你体重超标，你就会被健身房办卡或减肥食品的广告轰炸。但减肥的关键是少吃，而不是买新鞋或者吃蛋白粉。

Or, if you struggle with headaches and stress, they will try to sell you headache pills and antidepressants. But to really decrease stress, you should start sleeping and walking more instead of consuming entertainment products and browsing social media late at night. Pills are never designed to be a permanent solution: they lose power over time and cause side effects that will in turn require more pills. Once you embark on the endless journey of consumption, you get stuck in a trap designed to make you miserable and corporations happy.

或者说，如果你被头痛和压力所困扰，广告会极力向你推销头痛药和抗抑郁药。但如果真要减少压力，你应该开始多睡觉、多走路，而不是购买娱乐产品和熬夜刷社交媒体。药物绝不是永久的解决方案：随着时间推移，药物的效力会减弱；药物还会产生副作用，最后结果是你得吃更多的药。一旦你踏上无休止的消费之旅，你就会踏入一个精心设计的陷阱里，这个陷阱会让大公司感到快乐，但会让你十分痛苦。

Through evolution, Mother Nature has equipped us to efficiently cope with deficits of resources, but it never prepared us for life in the relative abundance we have now. Today, more people die from obesity than from hunger, and more people suffer from anxiety caused by information overload than from lack of news.

自然以进化的方式让我们获得了高效率地应对资源不足的能力，但自然没有为我们准备好应对当下资源相对丰富的生活的方式。如今，越来越多的人死于体重超标而不是饥饿，越来越多人的焦虑来源于信息超负荷而不是信息匮乏。

Human DNA, our hardware, is obsolete. It stopped evolving about 10,000-20,000 years ago when we still lived in small hunter-gatherer communities. Back then, every sweet bite and every piece of information was extremely valuable. We now live in megacities, surrounded by tons of cheap sugar, but our DNA doesn’t know that. Our bodies still accumulate excess fat to prepare for harsh hungry winters that never come. Our minds cling to every disturbing piece of news telling us about threats that never materialize.

我们的硬件——人类的 DNA，已经过时了。大概在一两万年前，我们还生活在狩猎群体中的时候，DNA 的进化就已经停止了。那时候，每一小口甜食、每一条信息都弥足珍贵。今天我们生活在大城市里，被廉价的糖所包围，这一点 DNA 并不知道。我们的身体还在为那不再到来的冬季储备多余脂肪，我们的头脑会紧紧抓住每一条告知我们威胁的新闻，这些威胁永远不会发生，但它们却让我们感到不安。

This biological paradox is made worse by our economic system which emphasises GDP growth and maximized corporate profits. People are encouraged to increase consumption by both governments and corporations. It’s not a coincidence that the US, a country that excelled in economic growth in the 20th century, is also the most obese developed country in the world. Their market-driven society became too efficient for its own good.

在我们这个强调 GDP 增长和追求公司利益最大化的经济系统下，这一生物学悖论显得更为糟糕。政府和大公司都在鼓励我们增加消费。美国是 20 世纪经济增速最快的国家，也是全球肥胖率最高的发达国家，这并不是巧合。他们这个由市场驱动的社会似乎过于有效了。

We became very efficient in making and selling ourselves stuff we don’t need, but it is the planet which pays the bill. As we keep destroying our own habitat in the eternal quest for economic growth, the number of diseases caused by pollution continues to rise.

I was lucky to become wealthy early in my life. By the time I was 22, I had a million dollars in my bank account, by 25 – tens of millions, by 28 – hundreds of millions. However, this has never been what made me happy.

我很幸运，年轻的时候就富裕起来了。在我 22 岁的时候，我的银行账户里就有了 100 万美金；到了 25 岁，这个数字变成了数千万；到 28 岁，这个数字则是数亿——但这从来不会带给我快乐。

My real luck was in realizing pretty early that the most rewarding kind of occupation is creating things, not consuming them. I spent most of my personal funds on Telegram for people to enjoy a free service that strives for perfection.

真正让我感到幸运的地方，是我很早地意识到了最有意义的职业是创造，而不是消费。所以我没有买游艇、飞机和昂贵的房产，而是把钱投到了最令我享受的东西上——创造（但愿能）给人类带来福祉的社交平台。我把我基金中绝大多数钱投到了 Telegram，让人们享受免费且力争完美的服务。

I consider the ability to create things for others the most valuable – and rewarding – asset of mine. I suspect one of the reasons I happened to get wealthy in the process of doing what I love is because money has never been an important goal for me.

我把为他人创造的能力视作我最宝贵，且最有意义的资产。我想我只是恰巧在做自己喜欢的事情的时候变得富有，因为对我而言，钱永远不是一个重要目标。

When I was a student, I liked building games and websites. Back then, it was considered an occupation for nerds. Promising students were expected to practice law or solve business cases. But I never really cared about how other people defined success. For me, success was in the ability to spend time creating things that I liked.

当我还是一个学生的时候，我喜欢制作网站和游戏。那时，人们认为这种事只有书呆子才会做，有前途的学生应该去从事法律工作或解决商业项目。但我从未关心他人是如何定义成功的，于我而言，成功在于能够花时间创造自己喜欢的东西。

I never regret not buying expensive stuff wealthy people like to surround themselves with. The only regret I have is not having more time to build things.

我从不后悔放弃那些富裕人士喜欢买来围绕在他们身边的东西，唯一令我感到遗憾的是，我没有更多用来创造的时间。

Not only is this system harmful to humans, it is also unsustainable in the long-term. Unlike corporate appetites, our planet’s resources are finite. We became very efficient in making and selling ourselves stuff we don’t need, but it is the planet which pays the bill. Our bodies still expect us to be living in the pristine environment we had 10,000-20,000 years ago, full of green forests and clean lakes. As we keep destroying our own habitat in the eternal quest for economic growth, the number of diseases caused by pollution continues to rise.

I was lucky to become wealthy early in my life. By the time I was 22, I had a million dollars in my bank account, by 25 – tens of millions, by 28 – hundreds of millions. However, this has never been what made me happy.

My real luck was in realizing pretty early that the most rewarding kind of occupation is creating things, not consuming them. So instead of buying yachts, airplanes and expensive real estate, I focused on what I enjoyed most – creating social platforms that (hopefully) bring good to humanity. I spent most of my personal funds on Telegram for people to enjoy a free service that strives for perfection.

I consider the ability to create things for others the most valuable – and rewarding – asset of mine. I suspect one of the reasons I happened to get wealthy in the process of doing what I love is because money has never been an important goal for me.

When I was a student, I liked building games and websites. Back then, it was considered an occupation for nerds. Promising students were expected to practice law or solve business cases. But I never really cared about how other people defined success. For me, success was in the ability to spend time creating things that I liked.

I never regret not buying expensive stuff wealthy people like to surround themselves with. The only regret I have is not having more time to build things.

We live in an era when the possibilities for human creativity are endless. One can invent robots, edit genes, design virtual worlds… There are so many exciting unknown areas to explore. I hope that more people will discover the enjoyment of building things for others. I hope that one day we, as a species, will turn away from the self-destructive path of never-ending consumption to a fulfilling journey of creating a better world for ourselves and those around us.

item.title: 再次暗淡无光
item.description: 成都发生的事情，为我国性少数本就黯淡无光的前途再次蒙上了一层阴影。
item.content:encoded:
Photo by Steve Johnson on Unsplash

 
注：本文所提及「性少数」基本是指代男同群体，不过因为 LGBTQ 群体构成比较多样，而且文章可能涉及到除男同外的其他群体，故使用「性少数」的表述。

写这篇文章主要是因为最近成都发生的事情。我之前其实写过一篇批判我国性少数群体的虚无主义的文章，但那时候并没有什么令人印象深刻的事件能唤起直观感受，加上那篇文章独断性太强，所以最后并没有写完。所以成都发生的事对我而言也不算特别意外，因为我国性少数群体开平权倒车已经不是一天两天了，甚至到现在已经跳过了平权，开始享受某种「特权」了，尽管我国性少数群体一直在一个隐秘的环境中生存的。

我不否认我国性少数群体生存的现状很大部分取决于官方对于性少数的问题缄口不言，但回顾性少数平权史，那些保障性少数权利的判决和法案，从来就不是从天上掉下来的，都是通过前辈们抗争得来的。说句不好听的，尽管我国性少数群体确实没有享受到和进步国家性少数相同的权利，但如今他们没有受到的严重打压，甚至能在公共言论环境中展示自己的性少数身份，这完全就是站在国外性少数前辈的肩膀上享受斗争成果。当然你可能说这是「歪屁股」言论，但仔细想想，由于传统观念的存在，在我国推行这样的思想本身就比外国难好几个台阶，加上各种行政管制，我们根本就不具备培植这种思想的土壤。所以我并不认为这种环境下能通过所谓经济发展、教育进步而让人们逐渐去接受性少数群体，我们现存关于性少数的观念，就是来自国外性少数前辈的抗争。

其实平权这事对于任何群体来说都不容易，别说性少数了，我国女权发展最近几年都收到了不小阻力，这边基本女权思想都鲜有人了解，各种乱七八糟的女权言论层出不穷，那边就已经开始用「性别一换，评论过万」和「极端女权」这种难以直接反驳的话来打压女权了。女权尚如此，性少数平权当然更为困难。就我这几年的观察，我国性少数群体目前似乎已经开始采取一种「放弃抗争」的态度了，他们转而开始专注于快感的享受。今年在美国上市的那个性少数交友平台，说是「交友」，其实在我看来那就是一个寻求肉欲的平台，而且在今天的中文公共言论环境中，性少数们很少真正去触及情感，而是直言不讳地表达出他们对肉体快感的诉求。

当然，我也明白很多人都认为肉体上的快感比情感真实得多，加上类似「道德是自律不是他律」、「人的基因决定其是寻求快感的动物」这种垃圾言论的广泛传播，人们不断赋予肉体快感以正当性。不过我并不打算反驳这些观念，我更想提一个更为基础问题：性取向究竟意味着什么？也就是说，性取向的差异使得性少数拥有了哪些与异性恋人群所不具备的特质？人并不会因为性取向的差异而出现某种生理构造的差异（就宏观而言，不深入到基因范畴），而且在性少数人群走进大众的视野前，很多性少数的人生轨迹还是和异性恋一样结婚生子，其生活看上去是与异性恋无异的；反过来，如今不少面向性少数的性工作者也不见得都是性少数，所以性取向差异并不能解释为「发生性关系对象的性别差异」。

这个道理其实大家都明白，但目前的问题在于，单纯对于肉体快感的追求，已经将性取向中真正的关键点——情感上的亲密——逐渐消解掉了，这样性少数和单纯性瘾的界限开始变得模糊，此时以性少数的身份去寻求情感上的亲密就会变得非常困难，需要花费更多的精力去进行甄别。

到这里你可能会说：异性恋也有私生活混乱、过着酒池肉林生活的人，凭什么只批判性少数的私生活？首先，我并不认为碰到这种问题时应该拿异性恋当挡箭牌，因为异性恋本身就拥有无需证明的合理性，而性少数目前需要做的则是去证明其存在的合理性，放弃证明自身合理性而借用异性恋的自然合理性来辩护，就是在承认：异性恋的合理性是比性少数高一等的，性少数受到压迫是合理的；此外，情感上的亲密关系被肉体关系消解，那么性少数的诉求，也就是希望法律能保障亲密关系，也就不复存在了，因为我们建立排他性的一对一关系，根本不是因为肉体关系，而是情感上的亲密关系。

当下，性少数确实是在偷偷地生活，但这并不代表性少数的选择只有「偷偷地做好人」和「偷偷地做坏人」，这不过是「必要之恶」的另一种精美包装。我们至少应该意识到，性少数并不注定是在地下苟且生存的一群人，性少数平权的意义就在于，能让性少数能从暗处走出来，坦坦荡荡地生活。最后，引用《罗马书》的一段话，既是约束自己，也是对同仁们的一点期望：

13:12 黑夜已深，白昼将近。我们就当脱去暗昧的行为，带上光明的兵器。
13:13 行事为人要端正，好像行在白昼。不可荒宴醉酒。不可好色邪荡。不可争竞嫉妒。

后记

写完这篇文章后，在发布前我去看了下成都事件的进展，官方当然不可能作出任何回应，不过这两天有篇描写事发地的微信文章传得非常火，然而这篇文章是 洗稿自四川大学学生自主创办自媒体「常识」早在 2018 年就发表的文章，也就是说性少数又一次成为了获取流量的工具。这是另一个需要提起注意的问题：当有人试图将某些真正紧要的问题弱化为「文化」，甚至拿来盈利时，那么问题本身的紧要性可能就在这一弱化过程被逐步消解掉了，最终则沦为资本主义用来得到增长的工具。

item.title: China’s devoted, combative celebrity fan clubs
item.description:
Photo by Pien Muller on Unsplash

 
为什么选这篇文章

  • 中英双语
  • 中文
  • 英文

A true fan downloads multiple copies of the same song and insults rival stars.
一位真爱粉会数次购买同一首歌，还会抹黑对家。

“The untamed”, a costume martial-arts drama, is one of the most-watched television series in China. Since its online release last year it has been viewed 8bn times. Its heart-throb star, Xiao Zhan (pictured), has gained a legion of fans. In October so many of them crowded an airport in Beijing to see him that they delayed a flight.

古装武侠剧《陈情令》是中国收视率最高的电视剧之一。自去年上线以来，它的播放量已达 80 亿次，主演该剧的明星肖战获得了一大批粉丝。去年 10 月，由于挤在机场想要见肖战的粉丝过多，导致了航班延误。

In February Mr Xiao’s devotees flooded the internet with complaints about a website hosting raunchy fiction about him. The government shut it down. In May a video went viral of a classroom full of primary-school students chanting: “Brother Xiao Zhan, you are very good!” The teacher who filmed them was suspended.

今年 2 月，肖战的追随者们在互联网上大规模地对一家网站进行投诉，该网站上有关于他的淫秽小说。5 月，一段拍摄于一间坐满了小学生的教室的视频流传开来，在视频中，小学生们高呼：「肖战哥哥，你真棒！」拍摄该视频的老师最终被停职。

Mr Xiao’s millions of admirers belong to what are known in Chinese as fanquan, or “meal circles” (because the word for meal sounds like the English word “fan”). These are passionate and sometimes combative online groups devoted to particular celebrities. The Chinese government has long demanded patriotism and good behaviour from stars, but it has placed few limits on fans. On the internet, where debate and organising are usually tightly controlled, fanquan enjoy rare freedom to do both.

在中文语境下，肖战的几百万粉丝都属于「饭圈」（因为「饭」这个词听起来像英文的「fan」）。「饭圈」通常以某一特定名人为中心，其行为往往充满激情、有时甚至富有斗争性。一直以来，中国政府要求明星热爱祖国、行为端正，但很少对粉丝做出限制。辩论问题和组织活动在互联网上通常会受到严格的控制，但粉丝在这两个方面却罕见地享有自由。

But as fanquan have grown, so too has official scrutiny of them. State media have criticised their “irrational” behaviour. Aviation authorities have pleaded with them not to stalk stars at airports. (Some fans buy information about their idol’s movements.) In May a member of China’s rubber-stamp parliament called on the government to “strictly rectify” fanquan because of the threat they posed to the “inheritance of red culture”. Mr Xiao, who is 28, has asked his fans to calm down. “I hope everyone puts their studies, work and life before chasing stars,” he said.

但随着饭圈的发展，官方对他们的审查也越来越多：国家媒体曾批评他们的「不理性」行为，航空当局请求粉丝不要在机场跟踪明星（有些粉丝会购买偶像的行踪信息）。今年 5 月，中国的一位人大代表呼吁政府「严格整顿」饭圈，因为他们会对「红色文化的传承」构成威胁。今年 28 岁的肖战要求他的粉丝们冷静下来，他说：「希望所有人把学业、工作、生活，都放在追星前面。」

Members of fanquan are mainly women in their 20s. Some teenagers join the fun, too. A government report shows that 12.8m internet users under 18 frequently engaged in “fan-support” activities. These include posting praise, attacking critics and insulting devotees of other stars. After Mr Xiao’s fans turned their guns on the sexually provocative fiction website, the site’s supporters boycotted brands he represented and filled their social-media pages with furious abuse. Among defamation cases that were heard by the Beijing Internet Court between January and November last year, nearly 12% were filed by celebrities, often against fans of rival stars.

饭圈的成员主要是 20 多岁的女性，这其中也不乏一些青少年。一份政府报告显示，有 1280 万 18 岁以下的网民经常从事「应援」活动，这些活动包括发布赞美的微博、攻击批评者和侮辱其他明星的支持者。在肖战的粉丝将枪口对准发布性挑逗小说的网站后，该网站的支持者开始抵制他代言的品牌，并在社交媒体页面上对其进行愤怒的谩骂。在去年 1 月至 11 月北京互联网法院审理的诽谤案中，有近 12% 的案件是由名人提起的，起诉对象往往是其竞争对手的粉丝。

Fandom also entails spending. Nearly 15% of fans born since 2000 lavish at least 5,000 yuan ($707) on their favourite stars each month—about 40% more than the average urban disposable income. Sometimes they crowdfund shows of affection, such as adulatory billboards in New York’s Times Square. More often they help celebrities ascend online charts. Take Mr Xiao’s latest single—he is also a singer— “Spot of Light”. In the first 48 hours after its release, it notched more than 25m downloads, a record. His fans reportedly helped by buying an average of nearly 66 copies each.

应援还包括了花钱。2000 年以后出生的粉丝中，有近 15% 的人每月至少为自己喜欢的明星花费 5000 元人民币（折合 707 美元）——大约比中国城镇人口平均可支配收入高出 40%。有时他们会用众筹的方式表达迷恋之情，比如纽约时代广场的那些谄媚的广告牌。更多的时候，他们会帮助名人登上网络排行榜。拿肖战的最新单曲《光点》来说——肖战也是一名歌手，在发布后的 48 小时内，下载量就超过了 2500 万次，创下了记录。据报道，他的粉丝平均每人购买了近 66 张。

Despite the unruliness of fanquan, the government may see occasional benefit in their ability to organise. After Wuhan, the city where covid-19 cases first soared, went into lockdown on January 23rd, fanquan raised and helped to distribute more than 7.4m yuan in relief money within about ten days. Last year, during pro-democracy unrest in Hong Kong, the mainland’s state media urged fanquan to praise “brother China” against critics abroad. 尽管饭圈不守规矩，但政府偶尔会从他们的组织能力中看到好处：1 月 23 日，新冠肺炎病例的爆发地武汉市进入封锁状态后，饭圈在十天左右的时间里就筹集了 740 多万元的救灾款并协助分配；去年香港发生动乱，官媒发动饭圈向国外的批评者赞美「阿中哥哥」，他们照办了，还对抗议者进行谩骂，共青团中央称这是 # 饭圈女孩为国出征 #。

But the fanquan are not always biddable. This year the League tried in vain to encourage their members to praise animated idols named after Mao Zedong’s writings. The idea was scrapped within hours.

In February Mr Xiao’s devotees flooded the internet with complaints about a website hosting raunchy fiction about him. The government shut it down. In May a video went viral of a classroom full of primary-school students chanting: “Brother Xiao Zhan, you are very good!” The teacher who filmed them was suspended.

Mr Xiao’s millions of admirers belong to what are known in Chinese as fanquan, or “meal circles” (because the word for meal sounds like the English word “fan”). These are passionate and sometimes combative online groups devoted to particular celebrities. The Chinese government has long demanded patriotism and good behaviour from stars, but it has placed few limits on fans. On the internet, where debate and organising are usually tightly controlled, fanquan enjoy rare freedom to do both.

But as fanquan have grown, so too has official scrutiny of them. State media have criticised their “irrational” behaviour. Aviation authorities have pleaded with them not to stalk stars at airports. (Some fans buy information about their idol’s movements.) In May a member of China’s rubber-stamp parliament called on the government to “strictly rectify” fanquan because of the threat they posed to the “inheritance of red culture”. Mr Xiao, who is 28, has asked his fans to calm down. “I hope everyone puts their studies, work and life before chasing stars,” he said.

Members of fanquan are mainly women in their 20s. Some teenagers join the fun, too. A government report shows that 12.8m internet users under 18 frequently engaged in “fan-support” activities. These include posting praise, attacking critics and insulting devotees of other stars. After Mr Xiao’s fans turned their guns on the sexually provocative fiction website, the site’s supporters boycotted brands he represented and filled their social-media pages with furious abuse. Among defamation cases that were heard by the Beijing Internet Court between January and November last year, nearly 12% were filed by celebrities, often against fans of rival stars.

Fandom also entails spending. Nearly 15% of fans born since 2000 lavish at least 5,000 yuan ($707) on their favourite stars each month—about 40% more than the average urban disposable income. Sometimes they crowdfund shows of affection, such as adulatory billboards in New York’s Times Square. More often they help celebrities ascend online charts. Take Mr Xiao’s latest single—he is also a singer— “Spot of Light”. In the first 48 hours after its release, it notched more than 25m downloads, a record. His fans reportedly helped by buying an average of nearly 66 copies each.

Despite the unruliness of fanquan, the government may see occasional benefit in their ability to organise. After Wuhan, the city where covid-19 cases first soared, went into lockdown on January 23rd, fanquan raised and helped to distribute more than 7.4m yuan in relief money within about ten days. Last year, during pro-democracy unrest in Hong Kong, the mainland’s state media urged fanquan to praise “brother China” against critics abroad. They duly complied, and launched tirades against the protesters. The Communist Youth League called it #thefangirlscrusade.

But the fanquan are not always biddable. This year the League tried in vain to encourage their members to praise animated idols named after Mao Zedong’s writings. The idea was scrapped within hours.
